metadata.description: Causal relationships extracted from scientific literature about edge cases related to fog, visibility, and measurement artifacts in PM2.5 monitoring

edge_cases.name: Fog-Induced PM2.5 Measurement Artifact
edge_cases.description: Light-scattering PM sensors detect fog droplets (liquid aerosols) as particles, causing overestimation of PM2.5 concentrations during fog events

relationships.mechanism: Fog droplets are liquid aerosols that scatter light similarly to solid particles. Light-scattering PM sensors cannot distinguish between fog droplets and actual PM particles, leading to false positive readings.

quantitative_evidence.description: PM concentrations increased linearly with RH below 70% in steam humidity tests

citations.authors: Kim, H., Kim, J., Roh, S.
citations.title: Effects of Gas and Steam Humidity on Particulate Matter Measurements Obtained Using Light-Scattering Sensors
citations.key_quote: The gaseous humidity did not cause errors in the PM measurements via the light-scattering method. In contrast, steam humidity, such as that caused by fog, resulted in errors in the PM measurement.

relationships.mechanism: At very high RH (>85%), hygroscopic particles absorb water and grow in size, increasing their light-scattering cross-section. This causes light-scattering sensors to overestimate PM mass concentrations.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sensor overestimation increases significantly at RH > 75%

citations.authors: Jayaratne, R., Liu, X., Thai, P., Dunbabin, M., Morawska, L.
citations.title: The influence of humidity on the performance of a low-cost air particle mass sensor and the effect of atmospheric fog
citations.key_quote: The sensor showed a high sensitivity to humidity, with the measured PM2.5 mass concentration increasing by a factor of 2-3 at RH > 85%.

edge_cases.name: Fog-Accelerated Sulfate Formation
edge_cases.description: Fog and low clouds provide aqueous-phase reaction environment that dramatically accelerates sulfate formation from SO2 oxidation, leading to rapid PM2.5 increase

relationships.mechanism: Fog droplets provide high liquid water content (LWC) environment where SO2 dissolves and is rapidly oxidized by NO2, HONO, H2O2, and O3. The high pH (>5.5) from elevated ammonia enables fast aqueous-phase oxidation.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sulfate production rate in cloud water can reach 0.5-1.3 μg m⁻³ h⁻¹, overwhelmingly exceeding gas phase and aerosol water pathways

citations.authors: Cai, S., Liu, T., Huang, X., Song, Y., Wang, T., Sun, Z., Gao, J., Ding, A.
citations.title: Important Role of Low Cloud and Fog in Sulfate Aerosol Formation During Winter Haze Over the North China Plain
citations.key_quote: High sulfur oxidation ratios (>0.6) under heavily polluted conditions are associated with low clouds and fog over NCP, induced by the moist southerly airflow.

citations.authors: Wang, J., Li, J., Ye, J., Zhao, J., Wu, Y., Hu, J., Liu, D., Nie, D., Shen, F., Huang, X., et al.
citations.title: Fast sulfate formation from oxidation of SO2 by NO2 and HONO observed in Beijing haze
citations.key_quote: Fog and cloud readily form under winter haze conditions, leading to high liquid water contents with high pH (>5.5) from elevated ammonia. Such conditions enable fast aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 by NO2.

relationships.mechanism: Rapid aqueous-phase oxidation of SO2 produces sulfate, while similar processes convert NOx to nitrate. These secondary inorganic aerosols (SIA) contribute significantly to PM2.5 mass.

conditions.aqueous_environment: fog droplets, cloud water, aerosol liquid water

quantitative_evidence.description: During haze episodes, transformation rates of sulfate and nitrate aerosols increase by 48% and 11% respectively through phase transition and increased ALW

citations.authors: Meng, X., Wu, Z., Chen, J., Qiu, Y., Zong, T., Song, M., Lee, J., Hu, M.
citations.title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation: insights into phase transition and its role in haze events
citations.key_quote: During haze episodes, the transformation rates of sulfate and nitrate aerosols rapidly increase through phase transition and increased ALW by 48% and 11%, respectively.

citations.authors: Cheng, Y., Zheng, G., Wei, C., Mu, Q., Zheng, B., Wang, Z., Gao, M., Zhang, Q., He, K., Carmichael, G., Pöschl, U., Su, H.
citations.title: Reactive nitrogen chemistry in aerosol water as a source of sulfate during haze events in China
citations.key_quote: The synergistic effect between nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide in the aqueous phase of aerosol particles can explain the rapid sulfate formation during severe haze events.

relationships.mechanism: Secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate, ammonium) directly contribute to PM2.5 mass. These hygroscopic species also promote further water uptake, creating positive feedback.

quantitative_evidence.description: PM2.5 increased from 210 μg/m³ in Stage I (moderate RH) to 330 μg/m³ in Stage II (high RH with fog), while sulfate increased fourfold from 10 to 40 μg/m³

citations.title: Fast sulfate formation from oxidation of SO2 by NO2 and HONO observed in Beijing haze
citations.key_quote: PM2.5 concentrations rose to over 400 μg m⁻³ during the high-RH period (Stage II) in concert with a rise in sulfate.

edge_cases.name: Clear-Sky High PM2.5 from Photochemical SOA Formation
edge_cases.description: Under clear sky conditions with intense solar radiation, photochemical oxidation of VOCs produces secondary organic aerosols (SOA), leading to elevated PM2.5 despite good visibility

relationships.mechanism: Intense solar radiation (especially UV) drives photolysis reactions that produce hydroxyl radicals (OH) and other oxidants. These oxidants initiate the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

quantitative_evidence.description: Under intense solar radiation, OOA production rate reached 15.0% h⁻¹ and intermediate VOCs at 14.0% h⁻¹

citations.authors: Wu, Y., Liu, D., Tian, P., Sheng, J., Liu, Q., Li, R., Hu, K., Jiang, X., Li, S., Bi, K., Zhao, D., Huang, M., Ding, D., Wang, J.
citations.title: Tracing the Formation of Secondary Aerosols Influenced by Solar Radiation and Relative Humidity in Suburban Environment
citations.key_quote: At lower pollution levels, the intense solar radiation caused substantial and rapid production of OOA (O/C = 0.81) and intermediate VOCs (both in a high oxidation state) at a rate of 15.0% h⁻¹ and 14.0% h⁻¹, respectively.

relationships.mechanism: Photochemical oxidation of VOCs by OH radicals produces low-volatility oxidized organic compounds that partition into the particle phase, forming secondary organic aerosol (SOA).

quantitative_evidence.description: Highly oxygenated OOA (O/C = 0.81) formed rapidly under strong solar radiation

citations.title: Tracing the Formation of Secondary Aerosols Influenced by Solar Radiation and Relative Humidity in Suburban Environment
citations.key_quote: These results highlight the feedback effects between radiation and moisture in terms of altering the formation mechanism of secondary aerosols.

relationships.mechanism: Clear sky conditions enhance photochemistry and SOA formation. Additionally, clear sky is often associated with stagnant high-pressure systems that trap pollutants near the surface.

quantitative_evidence.description: In all regions studied, clear-sky PM2.5 concentrations are generally higher than cloudy with some exceptions during winter

citations.authors: Christiansen, A.E., Carlton, A.G., Henderson, B.H.
citations.title: Differences in fine particle chemical composition on clear and cloudy days
citations.key_quote: In all regions, clear-sky PM2.5 concentrations are generally higher than cloudy with some exceptions during winter.

edge_cases.name: Aerosol Liquid Water Positive Feedback Loop
edge_cases.description: High RH causes particle phase transition from semi-solid to liquid, enabling accelerated heterogeneous chemistry that produces more hygroscopic species, further increasing aerosol liquid water

relationships.mechanism: At RH above 40-60%, particles transition from semi-solid/solid state to liquid state. This occurs when aerosol liquid water (ALW) mass fraction exceeds 15% of dry mass.

quantitative_evidence.description: Particles predominantly exist in semi-solid or solid state during clean winter days with RH below 30%. Phase transition occurs at RH thresholds of 40-60%.

citations.title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation
citations.key_quote: A non-liquid to liquid phase transition occurs when the ALW mass fraction exceeds 15% (dry mass) at transition RH thresholds of 40%–60%.

relationships.mechanism: Liquid particles enable faster heterogeneous and aqueous-phase reactions. Gas-phase species can more easily partition into liquid particles and undergo aqueous-phase oxidation.

quantitative_evidence.description: Sulfate and nitrate transformation rates increase by 48% and 11% respectively during phase transition

citations.title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation
citations.key_quote: The presence of abundant ALW, favored by elevated RH and higher proportion of SIA, facilitates the partitioning of water-soluble compounds from the gas to the particle phase.

relationships.mechanism: Production of secondary inorganic aerosols (sulfate, nitrate) and oxidized organic aerosols increases particle hygroscopicity, enabling more water uptake.

quantitative_evidence.description: Overall hygroscopicity parameters exhibit substantial enhancement with mean value of 23%

citations.title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation
citations.key_quote: Consequently, the overall hygroscopicity parameters exhibit a substantial enhancement, with a mean value of 23%.

relationships.mechanism: More hygroscopic particles absorb more water at the same RH, increasing aerosol liquid water content. This creates a positive feedback loop.

quantitative_evidence.description: Positive feedback loop between ALW and secondary aerosol formation during haze episodes

citations.title: Particle phase state and aerosol liquid water greatly impact secondary aerosol formation
citations.key_quote: These results highlight phase transition as a key factor initiating the positive feedback loops between ALW and secondary aerosol formation during haze episodes.

causal_chains.name: Fog → Measurement Artifact Chain
causal_chains.description: Fog directly causes PM2.5 measurement overestimation in light-scattering sensors

causal_chains.name: Fog → Accelerated Chemistry → PM2.5 Chain
causal_chains.description: Fog enables rapid aqueous-phase chemistry that produces secondary aerosols, increasing actual PM2.5

causal_chains.name: Clear Sky → Photochemistry → SOA → PM2.5 Chain
causal_chains.description: Clear sky conditions enhance photochemistry, producing SOA that contributes to PM2.5

causal_chains.name: High RH → Phase Transition → Positive Feedback Chain
causal_chains.description: High RH triggers particle phase transition, enabling accelerated chemistry that increases hygroscopicity and ALW in a positive feedback loop

key_findings: Fog droplets are detected as particles by light-scattering PM sensors, causing measurement artifacts (not actual pollution increase)
Fog and low clouds provide aqueous-phase reaction environment that accelerates sulfate formation by 0.5-1.3 μg m⁻³ h⁻¹, much faster than gas-phase pathways
Clear sky conditions can lead to higher PM2.5 than cloudy conditions due to enhanced photochemical SOA formation
High RH triggers particle phase transition that initiates positive feedback loops between aerosol liquid water and secondary aerosol formation
The distinction between measurement artifacts and actual pollution increase is critical for accurate air quality assessment
implications_for_hanoi: Hanoi's tropical humid climate with frequent fog events requires careful interpretation of PM2.5 sensor data
Winter monsoon cold surges bringing dry air followed by humid conditions can trigger rapid secondary aerosol formation
Clear sunny days in Hanoi can still have elevated PM2.5 due to photochemical SOA formation from traffic and industrial VOC emissions
Fog correction algorithms should be applied to light-scattering sensor data during fog events
